page.title: 14FARMING AROUND FLITWICK 2.
page.content: IN DRY SEASONS SOME CROP FAILURE IS LIKELY IN THE LIGHT SOIL, AS THERE IS NO IRRIGATION. THERE ARE NO LAKES NOR SUBSTATIAL RIVERS IN THE AREA, AND ALTHOUGH FARMERS HAVE TRIED VARIOUS METHODS OF IRRIGATION ALL HAVE PROVED TOO COSTLY. THERE ARE A FEW PRIVATELY OWNED SMALL HOLDINGS, ONE OF WHICH PRODUCES SOFT FRUIT WHERE CUSTOMERS PICK THEIR OWN PURCHASES. IN 1919 A TOTAL OF 272 ACRES, 140 ACRES NORTH OF FLITWICK WOOD AND 132 ACRES AT FROGHALL, WAS BOUGHT FROM THE DUKE OF BEDFORD BY THE COUNCIL. THIS WAS USED TO PROVIDE RETURNING LOCAL EX-SERVICE MEN WITH 1 OR 2 ACRES EACH. SOME LAND WAS STILL HELD IN THIS WAY UNTIL THE 1950S.
